title: The surprising origins of the word “lesbian” - Diane J. Rayor

title: Why I'm done trying to be "man enough" - Justin Baldoni

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the main reason men struggle to open up and be vulnerable with each other?

options.label: A
options.text: They are not interested in sharing their feelings.

options.label: B
options.text: They are afraid of being judged or seen as weak.

options.label: C
options.text: They are not comfortable with emotional conversations.

options.label: D
options.text: They are too busy with work and other responsibilities.

multiple-choice.question: The speaker mentions that he was surprised to find that his social media posts about vulnerability and authenticity were mainly responded to by women. What was his conclusion about this?

options.label: A
options.text: Women are more interested in vulnerability and authenticity than men.

options.label: B
options.text: Men are not interested in discussing vulnerability and authenticity.

options.label: C
options.text: Men are less likely to engage in conversations about vulnerability and authenticity due to societal expectations.

options.label: D
options.text: Women are more active on social media than men.

multiple-choice.question: The speaker shares a personal story about how he used to cut off his wife mid-sentence and finish her thoughts for her. What did he realize about this behavior?

options.label: A
options.text: It was a sign of his love and care for her.

options.label: B
options.text: It was a way of showing his dominance in the relationship.

options.label: C
options.text: It was an unconscious behavior that was hurting her and silencing her voice.

options.label: D
options.text: It was a habit he had developed due to his busy schedule.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the main reason for the glass ceiling and the problems women face in society?

options.label: A
options.text: Women are not working hard enough to achieve their goals.

options.label: B
options.text: Men are not doing enough to support and empower women.

options.label: C
options.text: Societal expectations and privilege are holding women back.

options.label: D
options.text: The glass ceiling is a myth and does not exist.

multiple-choice.question: The speaker quotes a passage from the Bahá'í writings that says, "The world of humanity is possessed of two wings, the male and the female. So long as these two wings are not equivalent in strength, the bird will not fly." What is the main message of this quote?

options.label: A
options.text: Men and women are equal and should have equal rights.

options.label: B
options.text: Men are stronger and more capable than women.

options.label: C
options.text: Women are more important than men in society.

options.label: D
options.text: The world needs both men and women to work together in harmony and equality in order to progress.

title: How to narrate your life story

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the difference between despair and hope?

options.label: A
options.text: The difference between success and failure

options.label: B
options.text: The difference between happiness and sadness

options.label: C
options.text: A different way of telling stories from the same set of facts

options.label: D
options.text: The difference between optimism and pessimism

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of a good narrator in telling one's life story?

options.label: A
options.text: To focus on the failures and mistakes

options.label: B
options.text: To blame oneself for every disaster or triumph

options.label: C
options.text: To be kind, intelligent, and fair-minded in narrating one's story

options.label: D
options.text: To ignore the painful and difficult experiences

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the significance of mistakes and failures in one's life story?

options.label: A
options.text: They are evidence of one's incompetence and foolishness

options.label: B
options.text: They are signs of how little information one has on which to base decisions

options.label: C
options.text: They are a sign of evil or bad luck

options.label: D
options.text: They are irrelevant to one's life story

multiple-choice.question: What is the importance of self-forgiveness in narrating one's life story?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows one to ignore one's mistakes and failures

options.label: B
options.text: It enables one to blame oneself for every disaster or triumph

options.label: C
options.text: It allows one to forgive oneself for the "horrors of our first drafts"

options.label: D
options.text: It is not important in narrating one's life story

multiple-choice.question: What is the ultimate goal of narrating one's life story, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a tale told by an idiot, signifying nothing

options.label: B
options.text: To create a tale told by a kind, intelligent soul, signifying rather a lot

options.label: C
options.text: To focus on one's successes and achievements

options.label: D
options.text: To ignore one's life story and focus on the present

options.label: D

title: An Exercise in Self Compassion

options.text: It can lead to increased motivation and productivity.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between shyness and introversion?

options.label: D

title: How to teach kids to talk about taboo topics - Liz Kleinrock

multiple-choice.question: What was the reaction of the class when Abby made a comment about people with dark skin?

options.label: A
options.text: The whole class remained silent.

options.label: B
options.text: Half of the class started laughing, and the other half started yelling at Abby.

options.label: C
options.text: The class started a discussion about the topic.

options.label: D
options.text: The teacher immediately reprimanded Abby.

multiple-choice.question: How did the teacher respond to Abby's comment?

options.label: A
options.text: The teacher yelled at Abby and embarrassed her in front of the class.

options.label: B
options.text: The teacher brushed off Abby's comment and changed the subject.

options.label: C
options.text: The teacher took the opportunity to explain why comments like Abby's are hurtful and to educate the class about racism.

options.label: D
options.text: The teacher asked Abby to leave the classroom.

multiple-choice.question: According to the teacher, what is the first step towards holding conversations about equity?

options.label: A
options.text: Building a common language and destigmatizing taboo topics.

options.label: B
options.text: Avoiding discussions about sensitive topics.

options.label: C
options.text: Providing students with a list of things they should not talk about.

options.label: D
options.text: Encouraging students to only discuss topics they are familiar with.

multiple-choice.question: How does the teacher approach teaching kids about equity in schools?

options.label: A
options.text: By giving them books to read on the topic.

options.label: B
options.text: By breaking down complex concepts into smaller, more manageable parts, and encouraging students to practice and ask questions.

options.label: C
options.text: By only discussing topics that are relevant to the students' lives.

options.label: D
options.text: By avoiding discussions about sensitive topics altogether.

multiple-choice.question: What do the students in the teacher's class believe about learning about issues of equity?

options.label: A
options.text: They believe they are too young to learn about these topics.

options.label: B
options.text: They believe it is a privilege to learn about these topics.

options.label: C
options.text: They believe they have the right to learn about these topics and that it is essential for their future.

options.label: D
options.text: They believe it is not relevant to their lives.
